title: Adding bookmarks using a mouse
content:
My dad is almost 89 years old. He is NOT TECH SAVVY. I have him using a trackball mouse. His hands are HUGE and his fingers are numb.

Somehow, he is inadvertently adding bookmarks to the bookmark bar. I do not know how he is doing this but he'll call and ask me to "put Gmail back on the bar". When I go over, there are a gazillion new bookmarks which pushes his Gmail bookmark beyond the >> spot. I have to delete these umpteen extra bookmarks so that the Gmail bookmark is visible again. Yesterday, I decided to move Gmail to the far left, hoping these accidental bookmarks he creates won't push it off the bar. The bookmarks he "creates" are specific gmail conversations, or facebook pages, or Publisher's Clearing House pages (he LOVES PCH games and plays them constantly).

HOW IS HE DOING THIS? He doesn't know enough to click the star button. He doesn't know about using the Ctrl and D keys to create a new bookmark. It's driving me BATTY. I'm sure he's somehow doing this using his mouse (clicking both right/left simultaneously but not aware of doing so).

Thanks in advance for helping a daughter keep her sanity ...
creator: romiha

content: This is the third time I've lost all my passwords (and logins) since the beginning of the year. I had over 200 when I lost it the first time. I've entered over 75 since then and today I just lost those. Fortunately, I had a backup of my profile. The old "key4.db" and "logins.json" files I had didn't work, although they have a significant size. In fact, looking at the "logins.json" using VS Code I see the logins are there but they don't display in the "Settings > Privacy & Security". How can I get access to them when this happens again. I was able to restore the profile from several days ago so I'm not completely in trouble.  :-)
creator: BPaul_H

title: Mozilla’s hostility towards .PDF generation
content:
Mozilla — PDF files must be SEARCHABLE! That's the WHOLE POINT of Adobe’s portable document format — that you can wean yourself off of paper and strap a rocket to what used to be contained in file cabinets by making the content INSTANTLY searchable.

Mozilla sigh. Why? Why are you so paranoid about enabling the User to generate web pages in PDF format? It’s positively baffling to me. I just don’t get it. Generate the equivalent of a brain dead document by saving it only as an unintelligible collection of zeroes and ones? An image???

HOW STUPID DO YOU THINK YOUR USERS ARE? My god you insult me. Not once has anyone at Mozilla given a satisfactory answer for the disabling of PDF generation ever since you gutted the last True version of Firefox many, many years ago. This needs to be not a future implementation but an IMMEDIATE, URGENT, TOP PRIORITY, DROP-EVERYTHING-ELSE-AND-IMPLEMENT-PDFS-IMMEDIATELY feature.

((NOW)) Mozilla.
creator: merry.widow

title: Firefox Does Not Play VR Content in Oculus Rift
content:
Hello,

I seem to be having a problem when playing any VR content in the latest default version of Firefox (97.0.1, 64-bit). When VR content is being displayed, I do not get a prompt to allow access to my VR headset in the address bar.

I have a first generation Oculus Rift CV1. In the Oculus software's settings, I have enabled Unknown Sources and selected it as my default OpenXR runtime (see attached image).

I would like to provide some suggestions as to what might be going wrong but I am unable to even hazard a guess. VR games and standalone applications work fine. It is almost as if Firefox doesn't recognise I have a VR-compatible device?

Thanks in advance for any support, -L
creator: simplelogin-newsletter.wip4w
